channel.title: CNN.com - World
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - World
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Arwa Damon: Freeze-frame moments
item.description: It was the war everyone just wanted to forget. But from a tiny red shoe in the rubble to a resident who rebelled against al Qaeda, CNN's Arwa Damon remembers the many freeze-frame moments caused by war.

item.title: Jessica Lynch, others: Where are they now?
item.description: Ten years ago this week, President George W. Bush announced the United States and coalition forces had begun military action against Iraq. Here's a look back at some of the people who made headlines during the war.

item.title: Photos: Enduring images
You won't believe what's in U.S. rivers
item.description: In the last 15 years, Chad Pregracke has helped pull more than 67,000 tires from the Mississippi River and other waterways across the United States. But that's just scratching the surface.

item.title: 'Brilliant Bus' shrinking digital divide
item.description: Working as a guidance counselor five years ago in Palm Beach County, Estella Pyfrom noticed that fewer students had access to a computer after school.

item.title: A way out of deadly N.J. streets
item.description: Camden, New Jersey, is not an easy place for a kid to grow up in.

item.title: Kenyan woman challenges tradition
item.description: Kakenya Ntaiya is inspiring change in her native Kenyan village after opening its first primary school for girls.

item.title: Make a foster kid's wish come true
item.description: One Simple Wish was started by Danielle Gletow to help grant the wishes of children in foster care. Each child's individual wish is posted online, and anyone can pay to make that wish come true --- from tangible items such as a bicycle, a varsity jacket or school supplies to an experience like music lessons or a trip to the theater.

item.title: Where pregnancy is feared, fatal
item.description: In many countries, women are dying during childbirth -- not because they lack proper health care, but because the delivery room is too dark.

item.title: When Buddhists pick up guns
item.description: For Thailand's Queen Sirikit, the 2007 attack on a minibus in southern Thailand's Yala province -- in which suspected Muslim militants shot eight Buddhists through the head in broad daylight -- was simply further proof of what she'd been saying for more than three years.

item.title: 10 captured by Taliban
item.description: Taliban insurgents seized an Afghan pilot and nine foreign nationals from a transport helicopter after it was forced to make an emergency landing late Sunday night in eastern Afghanistan, authorities said.

item.title: Nearly 200 die in China quake
item.description: Families badly in need of food and water are living in makeshift shelters near the shattered remains of their houses in this area of the southwestern Chinese province of Sichuan where a strong earthquake struck over the weekend, killing at least 192 people.

item.title: From CEO to wildlife photographer
item.description: What started as a hobby is now a mission for photographer Brian Hampton, CEO-turned-wildlife photographer.

item.title: Turning food trash to treasure
item.description: Patricia Wu looks at efforts to combat food waste in Hong Kong.

item.title: Urban farming looking up
item.description: Less than 20 miles from Singapore's skyscrapers is a completely different set of high-rise towers.

item.title: War separates family for 60 years
item.description: CNN's Anna Coren reports on one North Korean native's decades-long separation from his family.

item.title: A one-way ticket to Mars
item.description: Step right up and prove why you should get a one-way ticket to Mars! Well, wait -- you might want to know a little more about the venture first.

item.title: Why Venezuela is so divided
item.description: As if on cue, Ermelinda Briceno entered the makeshift shrine to Hugo Chavez and shed a tear. This place of reverence to "el Comandante," the president of Venezuela for 14 years, popped up in this poor neighborhood after Chavez's death last month.

item.title: A wake-up call for China?
item.description: China has one of the oldest food cultures in the world and, like that acme of Western food culture French cuisine, the food needs to be fresh.

item.title: The dilemma of U.S. drone strikes
item.description: The Sabaoon School for boys in northern Pakistan is anything but average.

item.title: France's Jewish exodus
item.description: With anti-Semitic attacks on the rise, many French Jews are choosing to leave the country, as Jim Bittermann reports.

item.title: Kidnapped to Egypt: Dad helpless
item.description: Nearly 12 years ago, Michael Shannon sent his two young sons to New York for what he thought what be a weekend visit with their mother. It would be the last time he saw either one of them.

item.title: Iran's cartoonists drawing fire
item.description: In 2003, former newspaper editor Ali Reza Eshraghi made a mistake that cost him his freedom: he published a cartoon.

item.title: Guatemala tackles dark chapter
item.description: The soldiers killed Jacinto Lopez's teenage daughter Magdalena by repeatedly stabbing her in the neck.

item.title: Rivals battle for control of Bolshoi
item.description: CNN's Phil Black reports on the two men bitterly fighting for control of Russia's world famous Bolshoi Ballet.

item.title: Dubai police add Lamborghini
item.description: Dubai Police have revealed the latest addition to their patrol fleet -- a Lamborghini Aventador.

item.title: Addicts shoot up legally in Canada
item.description: Heroin addicts shoot up with medical staff on standby should they overdose at North America's only legal safe haven injection center.

item.title: Auschwitz survivor searches for twin
item.description: Menachem Bodner is a soft-spoken 73-year-old, who thinks carefully before he describes his first memory as a three-year old child.

item.title: Inside Taliban suicide training
item.description: CNN's Nic Robertson talks to a journalist who spent a week in a Taliban suicide training camp.

item.title: Crews help worker trapped in mixer
item.description: Crews rescue a construction worker who fell into a cement mixer in China's Sichuan Province.

item.title: 'The toughest race on Earth'
item.description: Would you pay thousands of dollars to spend seven days running under the scorching sun of the Sahara Desert, traversing shifting sand dunes and punishing rocky plateaus for more than 220 kilometers, with all your food and kit affixed to your back?

item.title: Family pleads for jailed blogger
item.description: The message the brother and sister read aloud is one addressed to a missing father: 9-year-old Najwa and 8-year-old Tirad reciting the words in unison, "Our mother's starting to worry about you."

item.title: Sandstorm blurs city skyline
item.description: A strong sandstorm hit northwest China, disrupting traffic and spring farming.

item.title: Flash mob, Renaissance style
item.description: Actors in 17th-century costume hit Dutch mall to reconstruct a Rembrandt painting.

item.title: Terror plot on train thwarted
item.description: Two men were arrested after police say they planned to carry out an attack, with support from al-Qaeda elements in Iran, against a passenger train traveling between Canada and the U.S.

item.title: Raspberry Pi + Arduino = $100 PC
item.description: The UDOO (pronounced "you do") brings together the power of four Raspberry Pi's and the popular micro-controller Arduino to create a highly customizable PC for just $100.

item.title: Harvesting rubber from dandelions
item.description: Will your car and bicycle tires be made from dandelions in the future? A Dutch biotech firm thinks so. CNN's Nick Glass investigates how the ubiquitous weed's latex roots could help rubber shortages in the future.

item.title: Life-size robot for under $1,000
item.description: "It's about as difficult as assembling a cupboard from IKEA," says Gael Langevin, but he's not talking about an affordable piece of Scandinavian furniture. The 41-year-old French sculptor and model-maker is referring to his open-source, life-size, 3D-printed robot.

item.title: What was Tamerlan Tsarnaev doing in Russia?
item.description: Something struck Tamerlan Tsarnaev's aunt when her nephew arrived in southern Russia last year.

item.title: Rapes in India: 'Mindset hasn't changed'
item.description: Four months after a vicious gang rape left a 23-year-old physiotherapy student dead and triggered a national outcry over the treatment of women, more protests ignited in New Delhi after another brutal rape -- this time the victim was a five-year-old girl.

item.title: Bride covers quake in wedding dress
item.description: A reporter in the middle of getting ready for her wedding left the make-up chair to cover the Sichuan quake.

item.title: Mysterious structure at lake bottom
item.description: A mysterious, circular structure, with a diameter greater than the length of a Boeing 747 jet, has been discovered submerged about 30 feet (9 meters) underneath the Sea of Galilee in Israel.

item.title: Rangers risk lives for elephants
item.description: Last year, 60 park rangers were killed in the line of duty. But rangers in Cameroon are willing to risk their lives to save the African forest elephant.

item.title: India rapes: 'Mindset hasn't changed'
item.description: Four months after a vicious gang rape left a 23-year-old physiotherapy student dead and triggered a national outcry over the treatment of women, more protests ignited in New Delhi after another brutal rape -- this time the victim was a five-year-old girl.

item.title: 2nd arrest in rape of 5-year-old
item.description: Indian police have arrested a second man in connection with the alleged rape of a 5-year-old girl, a police spokesman said Monday.

item.title: N. Korea talks: Where they stand
item.description: A week of critical diplomacy is set to begin in Washington, Beijing and Pyongyang. But the sides are so far apart, at least in public declarations, it is impossible to predict where any diplomatic efforts will lead.

item.title: Family separated for 60 years
item.description: CNN's Anna Coren reports on one North Korean native's decades-long separation from his family.

item.title: Cherie Blair: I want to see full equality
item.description: Cherie Blair, the UK's former first lady, is a leading barrister who holds the senior advocate status of Queen's Counsel. In 2008, she founded the Cherie Blair Foundation for Women, where she devotes herself to supporting female entrepreneurs in Africa, South Asia & the Middle East. She spoke with CNN's Leading Women team about her commitment to eradicating injustice for women, her rise from a working-class family and how she balances her charity work with her professional life.

item.title: Sandberg: Men must speak up
item.description: Women have long dominated the heated discussion around gender equality. But one group not engaging in the conversation is men, says Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg.

item.title: The heiress and the bebop star
item.description: The jazz record was only three minutes long, but it was enough time to cast a spell on a wealthy European heiress who would give up her world for the New York jazz scene.

item.title: 12 women who changed business
item.description: From Weight Watchers to Chanel to China's largest recycled paper company, smart women have been behind many of the great businesses of the last century.

item.title: Car bomb explodes outside French embassy in Libya
item.description: A car bomb exploded just outside the French embassy in Tripoli early Tuesday morning, injuring two French security guards and a local girl, officials said.

item.title: Suspected terrorists arrested in Spain
item.description: Spanish police arrested two suspected terrorists with apparent links to an al Qaeda-affiliated group Tuesday but said they had no indication of an imminent attack.

item.title: Israeli official: Syria using chemical weapons
item.description: The Syrian government is using chemical weapons against rebel forces, the head of the Israel Defense Forces' intelligence research departments said Tuesday.

item.title: France's same-sex marriage bill OK'd
item.description: France is set to become the latest nation to legalize same-sex marriage Tuesday, despite vocal opposition from conservatives, when legislation goes before lawmakers in the lower house for a final vote.

item.title: Chinese, Japanese ships crowd disputed islands
item.description: The fragile relationship between China and Japan came under fresh strain Tuesday as ships from both sides crowded into the waters around a disputed group of islands and nearly 170 Japanese lawmakers visited a controversial war memorial.

item.title: Taliban capture 10 after chopper's emergency landing
item.description: Taliban insurgents seized an Afghan pilot and nine foreign nationals from a transport helicopter after it was forced to make an emergency landing late Sunday night in eastern Afghanistan, authorities said.

item.title: North Korea nuclear threats: Where it stands
item.description: A week of critical diplomacy is set to begin in Washington, Beijing and Pyongyang. But the sides are so far apart, at least in public declarations, it is impossible to predict where any diplomatic efforts will lead.

item.title: Search for survivors in China quake
item.description: Families badly in need of food and water are living in makeshift shelters near the shattered remains of their houses in China, where a strong earthquake struck over the weekend, killing more than 180 people.

item.title: Police arrest 2nd suspect in rape of 5-year-old
item.description: Indian police have arrested a second man in connection with the alleged rape of a 5-year-old girl, a police spokesman said Monday.

item.title: China bird flu cases jumps past 100
item.description: The number of bird flu cases in China jumped Sunday to 102, including 20 deaths, the World Health Organization announced.

item.title: London Marathon honors Boston victims
item.description: Despite the spring sunshine, the start of the London Marathon on Sunday was a somber occasion.

item.title: Europe at wit's end over austerity?
item.description: Europe may have hit the political limits of how far it can go with austerity-led economic policies because of the growing opposition in the eurozone's recession-hit periphery, the European Commission's president said on Monday.

item.title: Death ruled 'medical misadventure'
item.description: The death of an Indian dentist who died after a miscarriage in an Irish hospital was the result of medical misadventure, an inquest jury ruled Friday.

item.title: Venezuela's new president
item.description: Hugo Chavez's handpicked successor was sworn in as Venezuela's president on Friday.

item.title: Testimony in genocide trial nullified
item.description: More than three weeks of testimony in the genocide trial of former Guatemalan dictator Efrain Rios Montt were nullified by a judge Thursday on procedural grounds, state-run media reported.

item.title: Man forgotten in jail for 37 years
item.description: An elderly man's brain languishes. His body languishes, too, in prison. No one seems to know he's there.

item.title: Reports: Massacre near Damascus
item.description: CNN's Mohammed Jamjoom reports on information about a massacre in Syria, and death tolls continue to rise.

item.title: More than 30 killed in Iraq attacks
item.description: Violence erupted in Iraq on Tuesday, with more than 30 slain and dozens injured in an atmosphere beset with political and Sunni-Shiite tensions.

item.title: Clash ahead of Grand Prix race
item.description: Protesters clashed with police in Bahrain on Sunday before the start of the controversial Formula One race, which was won by world champion Sebastian Vettel.

item.title: Does Africa want 'celebrity saviors'?
item.description: Madonna, Angelina Jolie, George Clooney and Bono are some of the celebs pledging to "save Africa." But does Africa want them?

item.title: Rangers risk lives to save elephant
item.description: Deep inside Cameroon's Lobeke National Park a team of conservationists venture into the lush rainforest, weaving their way through the bush's narrow paths.

item.title: Kidnapped family released
item.description: A French family kidnapped in northern Cameroon earlier this year has been released, the Cameroonian government said Friday.
